fact.text: Cats are expert carnivores, and would never be caught dead eating a salad (unless it's a houseplant).
Domestic cats are basically tiny lions that have been demoted to house arrest and forced to wear embarrassing collars.
The scientific name for the domestic cat is Felis catus, but they much prefer to be called Sir or Madame Fluffernutter.
A group of cats is called a clowder, or, if they're feeling fancy, a feline entourage.
Cats have retractable claws, because sometimes even they need to take a break from being fabulous.
A cat's whiskers are highly sensitive and help them navigate and sense their surroundings, but mostly they just look really cute and add to their "mysterious" vibe.
Cats can run up to 30 miles per hour (48 kilometers per hour), but only if they're chasing a laser pointer or a piece of string.
The average cat lifespan is around 12-16 years, which is plenty of time to knock over at least a few dozen vases.
A cat's eyesight is much better in low light conditions than humans, but they still can't resist a good nap in a sunbeam.
Cats have a unique ability to rotate their ears independently, which is incredibly impressive until you realize they're just ignoring you on purpose.
The Maine Coon, or Felis catus gigantus, is the largest domesticated member of the family Feli-dae, weighing up to 25 pounds (11.3 kg), or approximately the same as a small farm animal.
Creme Puff, the oldest cat on record, lived to be 38 years and 3 days old, which is about 264 in cat years, or long enough to develop a keen interest in knitting and pottery.
Cats are members of the order Carnivora, or flesh-eating mammals, which is a polite way of saying they're the original meatheads.
A cat's sense of smell is 14 times stronger than a human's, allowing them to detect the scent of a tuna sandwich from approximately three miles away.

Domestic cats are believed to have been first domesticated in the Near East over 10,000 years ago, in what is now known as the Fertile Crescent, because apparently, cats have always had a thing for being on the cutting edge of agriculture.
The scientific name for the domestic cat, Felis catus, is derived from the Latin word "feles," which means "cat," and the Greek word "kata," which means "to judge humans from a lofty perch.

A cat's retractable claws are controlled by specialized muscles and tendons, which allow them to extend or retract their claws with the same level of precision as a Swiss watchmaker adjusting a tiny gear.

In ancient Egypt, cats were worshipped as sacred animals and depicted in art as goddesses, which just goes to show that even thousands of years ago, people knew better than to mess with a cat's sense of self-importance.

Cats have a natural instinct to scratch, which helps them stretch and keep their claws sharp, but also has the added bonus of providing humans with a never-ending source of entertainment as we try to keep our furniture intact.

Cats are incredibly agile and can jump up to 7 times their own height in a single bound, which is impressive, but also a bit unnerving, especially when they decide to do so in the middle of the night.
